item.title: Evident unto Itself
item.description: I enjoy sitting by a road, even when I’m alone. I don’t like being alone in a room. Even if I try to be, my body eventually revolts. But by being by the road, I can be alone and still not be far from people. In the background there is the effervescence of a moving traffic, a moving city. And when I want I can gaze up and encounter an “other”. Perhaps, being isolated, in a literal sense, is a great fear for me.

item.title: Scripture vs Science on the Creation Narrative
item.description:
It is not a wise thing to do to test scripture to align with the scientific narrative of creation, especially in terms of chronology of creation. This is not because they contradict, but simply because Scripture has metaphysical elements which science cannot take into account.

For example, time as we know it is demarcated by the objects in the space (heavenly bodies) and forces applied by them. These themselves are created in the third day of the Genesis narrative. So, what day 1 represents is not our familiar physical time (which was only created in day 3). Neither the order of the days represents the chronology of creation. Rather, the creation narrative should be seen from God’s perspective, which is outside time.

item.title: Friend of the Hero
item.description:
He was the other guy. No, not the one who was exchanging stares with the girl. He was sitting at the other table. He was quite glad seeing their little tale unfold in just gazes.

He wasn’t the one who put the ball through the hoop. He was just there by the court. Everybody cried the shooter’s name in unison. And he joined them too.

He was never the one who took walks in the fog. But he did listen when someone narrated conversations they had during those walks.

item.title: Piu
item.description:
Sitting at edge of the enormous cavea, I am facing its long flow down into the empty amphitheater. A swarm of young men and woman are aggresively dancing in the bars behind me to the beat of erotic music. Saturday nights here are loud and crowded. So it is quite unusual to see eight year old Piu jump down the empty flight of high stairs stretching before me.

I don’t know Piu at all. In her appearance she resembles my childhood friend with the same name. And hence I call her that too. For Piu the journey down is not yet comfortable. Every new jump she makes is just like her first one. Carefully thought and then acted out.
